exploration.p: Consider the function f(x) = e^x near a = 0. We know that f’(x) = e^x, so f’(0) = 1; along with the fact that f(0) = 1, it follows that the tangent line approximation is L(x) = f(0) + f’(0)(x-0) = 1 + 1(x-0) = 1 + x.

li.p:
Build a spreadsheet that computes the difference between f(x) and L(x) for x-values between -1 and 1, spaced 0.1 units apart. Your spreadsheet should start like the one shown in Table.
Comparing f(x) = e^x and L(x) = 1 + x near a = 0.
\Delta x x f(x) = e^x L(x) = 1+x
0.1 -1.0 0.36788 0.0
0.1 -0.9 0.40657 0.1
0.1 -0.8 0.44933 0.2
Next, add a column to your spreadsheet that computes |f(x)-L(x)|.
How do the differences between f(x) and L(x) change as you move across the interval from x = -1 to x = 1?
For about what values of x is it true that |f(x)-L(x)| \lt 0.1?

Next, to investigate the possibility of a better approximation than the tangent line, we consider the quadratic function Q(x) = 1 + x + \frac{1}{2}x^2. Add two columns in your spreadsheet to the right of your existing columns: one that computes Q(x), and another that computes |f(x)-Q(x)|. How do the differences between f(x) and Q(x) change as you move across the interval from x = -1 to x = 1?
For about what values of x is it true that |f(x)-Q(x)| \lt 0.1?
